answers.answer: yes, the vast majority of eye problems can be found during a dilated fundus exam.fluorescein angiography (FA) is only perfomed in cases of retinal/macular leakage or suspected leakage like in diabetes and macular degeneration, for example.  not a test you would get for complaning of "greyed out" vision.ERG's are fairly rare.  really pretty much used in clinical research settings to study optic nerve problems and neuro-ophthalmic disorders.  also unlikely to get an ERG with complaints of "greyed out" vision.so why did your doctor not order more tests?  he/she thinks or assumes this is a neurological problem with a visual manefestation.  these disorders are nearly impossible to diagnose, and 99% of the time totally untreatable.  so even if they ordered a bunch of expensive and time consuming tests, the results would very likely be inconclusive...and even *if* they came up with a diagnosis, there would also be a very high probability that it would be totally untreatable.

any eye or vision problem that s not diagnosed during an eye exam is assumed to be a BRAIN problem.  that does sound scary, but:80% of your brain is devoted to vision.  i'm not kidding.  receiving the image, "flipping" the image, processing the image, fusing the right and left image wit each other, coordinating eye movements, visual memory, etc etc ad nauseum.  literally only 20% of your brain is for everything else: breathing, thinking, etc etc.  i am not exaggerrating.so if you have some problem with your vision, and your eye is FINE, then there's something wrong with some part of that 80% of your brain.  MS, tumor, aneurysm, blood flow problems, migraine, etc...or even just perceptual problems with the way you "process" visual information.some of these are treatable with brain surgery or medications.  most of them are not treatable.IMO the majority of vision problems not diagnosed during an eye exam that are also not attributed to any serious tumor, etc are probably untreatable.
